nodes.body:
Whereas this case[1] is not used much in Spoken Tibetan, it is very common in the literary language. The associative དང་ goes with a small class of verbs and adjectives, some of which occur quite frequently:

  • ལྡན་ “To possess”
  • བཅས་ “To possess”
  • འགལ་ “To infringe,” “to go against”
  • མཚུངས་ “Comparable with”
  • མཇལ་ “To meet”(H),
  • ཐུག་ “To meet”
  • མཐུན་ “To be in agreement (with)”
  • སྟུན་ “To agree,” “to harmonize”
  • འཐབ་ “To fight with”
  • ཐག་ཉེ་ “To be close (to)”
  • འགྲོགས་ “To be associated with,” “to be accompanied by”
  • སྦྲགས་ “To tie”
  • སྦྱར་ “To stick”
  • ལྷན་ “To be together”
  • མཉམ་པོ་ “To be (with)”
  • འདྲེ་ “To mingle (with)”
  • སྦྲེལ་ “To connect,” “to attach”
  • སྡེབ་ “To join”
  • དམག་བརྒྱབ་ “To make war (on/against)”
  • བྲལ་ “To be separated (from),” “to be deprived (of)”

Following are some example sentences using the associative:

  • ནང་པ་དང་ལྟ་བ་མི་མཐུན་པའི་དུས་ཤིག་ཡོང་། “A time will come when there will be a philosophical position hostile to Buddhism.”
  • མི་བཟང་པོ་དང་ཐུག་ “To meet an excellent person”
  • ཁྲིམས་དང་འགལ་བ་ “To break the law”
  • ང་ཨ་མ་དང་ཡུད་ཚམ་ཞིག་ཕྲད། “I shall meet my mother (if only) for an instant.”
  • ལྷ་མིན་ལྷ་རྣམས་དང་འཐབ་ཏུ་འགྲོ “The titans are going to make war on the gods.”

As in Spoken Tibetan, the marker may also function as a coordinating conjunction, “and” (xxlink mst 9.3). It also acts as an imperative marker (xxlink mst 19.3). In Literary Tibetan, it is also used to introduce temporal clauses: “as soon as, when.”

  • ཉི་མ་ཤར་བ་དང་ཕྱིན་པ། “They set off as soon as the sun rose.”

[1] In The Classical Tibetan Language (Albany: State University of New York Press, 1992), Stephan Beyer proposes that དང་ be treated as a case, but he provides no arguments for his analysis, which is not supported by Tibetan grammars. However, the suggestion is a good one, and a number of arguments may be cited in support. དང་ cannot be preceded or followed by any other case markers. In other dialects, such as Ladakhi, དང་ marks the instrumental and the associative. In Central Tibetan, དང་ may be replaced by other cases such as the oblique or the absolutive. Like all the other case markers, the absolutive, the genitive, the agentive, the ablative and the oblique, the associative marker has two kinds of functions: case-related and connective. It should also be noted that in Amdo, the usual marker that corresponds to the Central Tibetan དང་ is ལ་, which is also a case marker.

This being said, there are two features that give the associative a special character: ﬁrst, contrary to other case markers, དང་ usually goes before the main verb, with which it has a close relation; and secondly, there are relatively few verbs that can take this marker, so that the case function of དང་ is rather rare.
nodes.title: About The Associative
